Title: Best practice: Make entire site SSL / HTTPS and issues that still apply today in 2012?
BodyMarkdown:
**Note:** There are existing question that look like duplicates (linked below) but most of them are from a few years ago. I'd like to get a clear and definitive answer that proves things either way.

##Is making an entire website run in HTTPS not an issue today from a best practice and performance perspective?

**Context:**
The conversation came up when we wanted to introduce some buttons that spawn lightboxes with forms in them that collect personal information (some of them even allow users to login). This is on pages that make up a big portion of the site. Since the forms would need to collect and submit information securely and the forms are not on pages of their own, the easiest way we could see to make this possible was to make the pages themselves be HTTPS.

What I would like is for an answer that covers issues with switching a long running popular site to HTTPS such as the ones listed below:

 1. Would a handshake must be negotiated on every request?
 1. Will all assets need to be encrypted?
 1. Would browsers not cache HTTPS content, including assets?

Title: Are Single Quotes Valid in a Doctype?
BodyMarkdown:
As stated in [this question][1], single quotes in html has either become more popular or we have begun to notice them more often.

Regardless, I have a related question.  The `HTML 4.01 Strict` doctype as shown at [w3schools][2] (below) uses double quotes.

    <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN"
        "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd">

As stated in the [accepted answer][3], single quotes are perfectly valid. However, the quoted values in the doctype aren't necessarily attributes so are single quotes permitted?  In other words, is the following a valid doctype?  Furthermore, if this is valid HTML, is it accepted by modern browsers?

    <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC '-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN'
        'http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd'>

Also, does the same hold true for XML doctypes?

    <?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>

  [1]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/242766/when-did-single-quotes-in-html-become-so-popular
  [2]: http://www.w3schools.com/tags/tag_doctype.asp
  [3]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/242766/when-did-single-quotes-in-html-become-so-popular/242775#242775

Title: Alternatives for replacing text selection under Outlook with custom HTML code
BodyMarkdown:
I need to replace an user selection while editing an Outlook e-mail with my custom HTML code.

I tried two approaches:

###Using the Clipboard###

 1. In HTML mode.
 1. Getting the Word.Range from the Word.Selection.
 1. Doing a range.Copy() to put it in the clipboard
 1. Convert inputString to outputString
 1. Replacing the selection with outputString with range.PasteSpecial(...)

###Using the Open XML Format###

 1. In HTML mode.
 1. Getting the Word.Range from the Word.Selection.
 1. Doing a range.Copy() to put it in the clipboard
 1. Convert inputString to outputString (in Office Open XML format, knowing how to craft it to produce a specific HTML).
 1. Replacing the selection with outputString with range.InsertXML(...)

The issues are:

 1. When using the clipboard it crashes sometimes. There are references about checking the clipboard state but I think I've tried the known alternatives.
 1. To use the insertXML you need to have Microsoft Word installed. You can't do an insertXML with Outlook installed alone. Look at: [Impact of deploying Outlook 2007 without Word 2007][1] for further information.

Do you know more alternatives? I can think of adding the elements myself like using InsertParagraph, but I am not sure if I can add hyperlinks or will experience similar issues.






  [1]: http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc179031%28v=office.12%29.aspx

Title: BBCode, what is the point?
BodyMarkdown:
For some time now I was wondering why one would choose to use BBCode? Ok alright I know that supposedly it's more secure (XSS prevention), but I find all that quite questionable and even if it is(which i highly doubt) it still might be not worth increased complexity:

 - First if you only support couple simple tags like [i], [u] there is really not much difference in looking for [i] or <i> tags in text.
 - Second by definition BBCode's and HTML's purpose is identical - markup of text and BBcode does not improve on HTML in any way (aside from dubious security claims) in comparison to lets say Markdown which is significantly more human readable than ether of those.
 - BBCode has no standart, there is some supposedly common set of stuff, but overall it seems very much like - make stuff up as you go along
 - If you choose to use BBCode, you now have one more language at your project and introducing multiple languages to project is rarely a good idea unless it brings significant benefits.
 - If you use more complicated BBCode you have to have BBCode to HTML converter and here one could argue what is easier - securing subset of HTML that you need, or writing good parser. Besides there are free libs for HTML cleanup, so again why use additional language?
 - If you choose to use JavaScript rich text editor, like CKEditor or TinyMCE, and you still want to store BBCode you have to write code for conversion from HTML to BBCode, possibly in JavaScript, so again even more code that might harbor nasty bugs. Also when writing converters you have to remember - there is no standart!

From all of this it seems to me that BBCode is lousy choice. However it seems that lots of people on the web are convinced that is great. I'm calling it into question. Maye I'm missing some elephant in the room of why it's so great? Maybe here I could find someone that sees my mentioned points as significant? (I think I only saw such points mentioned once somewhere)
